fields.value: Replication data for: Commodity Market Dynamics and the Joint Executive Committee, 1880-1886

publicationCitation.value: Mariuzzo, Franco, and Walsh, Patrick Paul, (2013) "Commodity Market Dynamics and the Joint Executive Committee, 1880-1886." Review of Economics and Statistics 95:5, 1722-1739.

files.description: This file contains the date, the spot and future price of corn as quoted in the New York Stock Exchange, and the Chicago spot price of the same commodity as exchanged in the Chicago Stock market. The weekly spot prices for both cities and the future price for New York were collected by Coleman in the Thursday edition of the New York Times; the spot prices refer to the preceding day, Wednesday. The dataset provides weekly observations from the period 01-Jan-1878 to 27-Dec-1887. The date is expressed as day-month-year. The various commodity prices refer to bushels corn (about 56 lbs) and have to be converted in 100lbs corn, for this later is the unit of the measurement used in Porter???s data (the conversion is executed in the file Datageneration1.do, see below). The variable GPN is the spot price for one bushel of corn as quoted in the New York (N) Stock Market; GP1N is the future price for delivery within the month; GPC is the spot price for 1 bushel corn as quoted in the Chicago (C) Stock Market
files.label: Commodityprices.tab

dataFile.description: This file contains the date, the spot and future price of corn as quoted in the New York Stock Exchange, and the Chicago spot price of the same commodity as exchanged in the Chicago Stock market. The weekly spot prices for both cities and the future price for New York were collected by Coleman in the Thursday edition of the New York Times; the spot prices refer to the preceding day, Wednesday. The dataset provides weekly observations from the period 01-Jan-1878 to 27-Dec-1887. The date is expressed as day-month-year. The various commodity prices refer to bushels corn (about 56 lbs) and have to be converted in 100lbs corn, for this later is the unit of the measurement used in Porter???s data (the conversion is executed in the file Datageneration1.do, see below). The variable GPN is the spot price for one bushel of corn as quoted in the New York (N) Stock Market; GP1N is the future price for delivery within the month; GPC is the spot price for 1 bushel corn as quoted in the Chicago (C) Stock Market

files.description: Datageneration1.do: Loads the files Commodityprices.dta and Transportationrates.dta, converts bushels in lbs, generates some key variables as described in Table 1 p. 1724, and saves the content in the file Datageneration1.dta.
files.label: Datageneration1.tab

dataFile.description: Datageneration1.do: Loads the files Commodityprices.dta and Transportationrates.dta, converts bushels in lbs, generates some key variables as described in Table 1 p. 1724, and saves the content in the file Datageneration1.dta.

files.description: Datageneration2.do: Loads the data files Datageneration1.dta and firmdata.dta. It creates additional variables that are explained in Table 1, p. 1724 in the article. Also, it does save the new data files railPO.dta and railPR.dta which are used to estimate PN and PRN in Matlab, based on the methodology suggested in Lee and Porter (1984). The estimated time series for PN and PRN are produced in Matlab (see Matlab section below), and then converted in Stata as pn.dta and pnnew.dta (the latter is PRN in the notation of the article). The variables that are relevant to for most of the estimations and figures in the article are saved in the file Datageneration2.dta.
files.label: Datageneration2.tab

dataFile.description: Datageneration2.do: Loads the data files Datageneration1.dta and firmdata.dta. It creates additional variables that are explained in Table 1, p. 1724 in the article. Also, it does save the new data files railPO.dta and railPR.dta which are used to estimate PN and PRN in Matlab, based on the methodology suggested in Lee and Porter (1984). The estimated time series for PN and PRN are produced in Matlab (see Matlab section below), and then converted in Stata as pn.dta and pnnew.dta (the latter is PRN in the notation of the article). The variables that are relevant to for most of the estimations and figures in the article are saved in the file Datageneration2.dta.

files.description: The dataset is made of firm-level data, with information on market shares, allotted market shares, etc. The first variable is week (1 to 328). The data contains information on the shipments of grain, suffixed (G), flour (FL), and provisions (P). Weekly reported prices for the three commodities are GR, FLR and PR, respectively. Shipments for each of the eight railway lines, for each of the three commodities, are included, together with each line???s target percentage allotment (with suffix AL). The lines??? prefixes are MC, LS, FW, PH, BO, GT, NP, and CA. Thus, BOG is the weekly grain shipment of the Baltimore and Ohio, in tons. The lines are not all independent companies. The New York Central consisted of the MC, LS, and NP lines. Similarly, the FW and PH lines are jointly held. Thus there are five separate firms. We got this dataset from Porter.
files.label: firmdata.tab

dataFile.description: The dataset is made of firm-level data, with information on market shares, allotted market shares, etc. The first variable is week (1 to 328). The data contains information on the shipments of grain, suffixed (G), flour (FL), and provisions (P). Weekly reported prices for the three commodities are GR, FLR and PR, respectively. Shipments for each of the eight railway lines, for each of the three commodities, are included, together with each line???s target percentage allotment (with suffix AL). The lines??? prefixes are MC, LS, FW, PH, BO, GT, NP, and CA. Thus, BOG is the weekly grain shipment of the Baltimore and Ohio, in tons. The lines are not all independent companies. The New York Central consisted of the MC, LS, and NP lines. Similarly, the FW and PH lines are jointly held. Thus there are five separate firms. We got this dataset from Porter.

files.description: This file contains the date and the transportation rates for: the Lakes and Canals (GRLC), the Lakes and Railroads (GRLR), All Railroads (GRAll), the JEC (GR). The dataset provides weekly observations for the period 01-Jan-1878 to 27-Dec-1887. The date is expressed as day-month-year. The transportation rates refer to bushels grain.
files.label: Trasportationsrate.tab

dataFile.description: This file contains the date and the transportation rates for: the Lakes and Canals (GRLC), the Lakes and Railroads (GRLR), All Railroads (GRAll), the JEC (GR). The dataset provides weekly observations for the period 01-Jan-1878 to 27-Dec-1887. The date is expressed as day-month-year. The transportation rates refer to bushels grain.
